content: Microsoft delivered another blowout earnings report Tuesday, tallying its best-ever quarterly revenue for its fifth quarter in a row – a stretch directly coinciding with an explosion in investor interest in artificial intelligence and Microsoft-backed OpenAI’s debut of ChatGPT. Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella speaks at CES 2024 earlier this month. Microsoft’s $62 billion of sales in the three-month period ending last month topped average analyst estimates of $61.1 billion, according to FactSet, while its $2.93 earnings per share topped forecasts of $2.77. The booming sales topped the prior quarter’s record $56.5 billion, marking an 18% year-over-year increase. Profits were slightly down last quarter, as the $21.9 billion in net income compared to the September quarter’s $22.3 billion profit, but profits remained up about 30% on an annual basis. Microsoft shares dipped slightly following the earnings report’s release, moving against the stock’s sweltering stretch, with shares up 11% in 2024 and 70% since the beginning of 2023. 30%. That’s how much year-over-year revenue growth Microsoft reported in its intelligent cloud division encompassing its AI-heavy Azure cloud service. Microsoft   a $3 trillion market capitalization for the first time ever last week, and was the most valuable company in the world as of Tuesday’s market close. Microsoft’s valuation narrowly topped that of Apple, which held the mantle of world’s biggest company for a majority of the last three years until Microsoft reclaimed the throne earlier this month. The Washington-based Microsoft has enjoyed a renaissance on Wall Street largely due to the legacy tech firm’s position as the   of the broader AI movement. Apple will report earnings Thursday afternoon, as will fellow big tech firms Amazon and Meta.

title: Shell Bay: Golf’s Newest $1 Million Club Towers Above Miami Market
content: An aerial rendering of the new Shell Bay development in the Miami area, a private enclave that has a  “There are way more people who want an amazing golf experience in the Miami region than there are available amazing golf experiences,” explains Alex Witkoff, the co-CEO of the Witkoff Group and a developer of one of the most unique new private clubs in the world. In Hallandale Beach, Florida, just north of Miami, the Shell Bay Club is tucked on a prime piece of land between the Atlantic Ocean and Intracoastal Waterway. And golf is the focal point of the 150-acre luxury development, with a new championship course that demonstrates the delicate balance between supply and demand in a major market. Shell Bay is the first private club in the Miami area in more than two decades and the price of membership for what its founders are calling a “generational opportunity” is well over $1 million. And there’s a waiting list to get in. “People want the best of the best and, given that there hadn't been an experience like this delivered in a few decades and it won't be replicated, the response has been extraordinary,” said Ari Pearl, the founder and president of PPG Development, another founding partner in the Shell Bay project. “It’s been global in nature,” added Pearl, who has been a prominent figure in the South Florida real estate and development industry for more than two decades. “We have people from New York, Chicago, Los Angeles. Also internationally, Europe and Asia, in addition to locally in Miami.” Greg Norman's design team has created a completely new course at the Shell Club just north of Miami.  The game of golf is unquestionably booming in popularity in recent years, but Shell Bay epitomizes the challenge of preserving golf on exceptionally valuable real estate in the heart of a crowded metropolitan market. Consider that Melreese Country Club, about 20 miles away and the only municipal golf course in Miami (one of the most populous metropolitan statistical areas in the country), closed for good last year in favor of a redevelopment project that will include a Major League Soccer stadium, hotels, an office park, and a retail area with shops and restaurants. It’s a massive project, one that will create thousands of jobs and generate billions of dollars in rent payments to the city over the life of a 99-year lease. Melreese had a storied history and was a successful and beloved public golf course, generating hundreds of thousands of dollars in annual net revenues for the city. But what is the realistic lifespan for a facility in such a prime location, on land next to Miami International Airport? In that case, and with the push and pull between supply and demand, it was demand for land that won out over the demand for golf – due to dollars signs. So, to make golf at Shell Bay Club viable in such a prime location, it’s become an outlier in several respects. The first is the cost to get in. Golf is the centerpiece to the new Shell Bay Club, a luxury development just north of Miami. It's  At well over $1 million, Shell Bay has one of the most expensive membership buy-ins of any golf club in the nation, the byproduct of what Witkoff says is a “vicious dearth” of golf in the market. “Land is very hard to accumulate in South Florida,” he said. “I don't see this ever being able to be replicated in the Miami region because I don't see where else you would get this amount of land close to the ocean. So, for us there was a kind of once in a generation opportunity to deliver a state-of-the-art golf facility and then with so much more — residences, tennis and so on and so forth.” Among the luxury amenities at Shell Bay, which is also partnering with Auberge Resorts to provide a 60-room boutique hotel and spa on property, is a tennis facility run by the renowned Bryan brothers that has courts with all four grand slam surfaces, not to mention pickleball and Padel courts. There’s a basketball court, batting cages, bowling alleys, a billiard room, and a 48-slip yacht club. Rendering of the private, multimillion dollar residences that overlook the new golf course at Shell  But the centerpiece is the golf course. There was once another course on the property, part of the old Diplomat Golf Resort. That’s long gone, as all the original holes were blown up and sand-capped, with Greg Norman’s team adding elevation changes and creating a completely new design – one that includes an 18-hole championship course and a 9-hole Par 3 layout, along with a 12-acre, state-of-the-art practice facility. Every lake on property was moved, so Shell Bay’s golf course really was reconstructed from the subgrade up, and with 4,000 new trees added (along with 1,000 different plant species) every playing corridor has completely changed from what was there before. More than 4,000 new trees were planted at the Shell Bay Club as part of the complete reconstruction  With a variety of risk-reward shot-making options and waterfront challenges, the new course can stretch to over 7,200 yards, making it one of the longest in golf-rich South Florida. The property was designed with visions of hosting a professional tournament in mind — with contoured greens and sweeping Australian sandbelt-style bunkers — and the Norman ties certainly make a future LIV Golf event in Miami market a distinct possibility, especially when you consider that LIV golfers like Bubba Watson, Patrick Reed, Henrik Stenson and Lee Westwood are members. Another unique element of the Shell Bay project that’s made keeping golf a component of the development a reality is the residential tower with 108 bespoke condominiums and penthouses. While more commonplace in some densely populated Asian countries, U.S. golf courses with a neighboring tower – whether residential, hotel or otherwise – is rare. “Building a tower was a no brainer,” said Witkoff. “It's very rare to have 150 acres in such a prime urban area within a major MSA. We’re able to build a tower and it makes sense to do it, more so than on a random Caribbean island or Montana or Wyoming. The opportunity to get this is unique.” In keeping golf as a core part of the Shell Bay project, a parcel of prime real estate was set aside  Residences are selling for between $2 million and $11 million, and while there’s a social membership to the club that comes with owning a home in the luxurious gated community, access to the golf course is separate. The course also won’t be an amenity for future guests of the boutique hotel when it’s completed. A golf club with a membership costing more than $1 million is not common, by any means. But either is a new high-end course (and community) that’s water accessible in a bustling metro area like Miami. And it appears the demand is there at Shell Bay. For land and for golf. “Golf is the background and canvas for the development,” said PPG’s Pearl. “The golf course is the backdrop but you’re also getting views of the ocean and the Intercoastal, with residences overlooking the marina and the tennis center. When you come through those gates, you’re in a real urban oasis.” With a new Greg Norman-designed championship course that aspires to host professional golf

title: The Rock’s Comeback Has Almost 300,000 Dislikes Amid Cody Rhodes Drama
content: The Rock returned to WWE, and fans are furious. The Rock came back on SmackDown (again) Friday night, and fans are furious. Sure, many fans in Birmingham, AL chanted his name, and were excited to see an unannounced appearance by The Rock. But as the dust settles and this storyline marinates, it’s leaving a very bad taste in a lot of people’s mouths. WWE posted Rock’s latest return on YouTube, and it’s a good thing YouTube disabled the dislike button, because fans are making full use of the toxic tool. The Rock is threatening to steal Cody Rhodes’ WrestleMania spot, and the comment section  “Felt so out of character when Cody left the ring. You win the rumble, almost beat Roman last year, wants the title for his father.. but gives it up to The Rock? Sad,” said one user to the tune of 23,000 likes. “71,000 likes, and 267,000 dislikes. If that doesn't tell you how the people feel about this bs [sic], then I don't know what else will,” read one comment. As of this writing, the   have swelled to 281,000. “Cody couldn't say he's more CM Punk without having the full Dwayne experience,” read one comment. “What was all that about, “Cody needs adversity?” What adversity has the Rock faced in the two years Cody’s been back? Hollywood championship indeed,” one user astutely pointed out. “The Rock taking advantage of his creative position to be the main event, sounds like Hulk Hogan.” Finally, one user wrote “Vince may have been gone, but his spirit lives on.” Terms like “Poor Cody,” “WE WANT CODY” and   are trending on Twitter. As I  , The Rock inserting himself in a WrestleMania main event as a Board Member is a bad look, and is certain to turn him heel. After years of Cody Rhodes vowing to finish his story, and fans with him every step of the way, Cody Rhodes willingly rented out his book to The Rock. Like a bleached-blonde book club. Whether WWE knows it or not, the expiration date for Cody to finish his story is WrestleMania 40. Not a second after. Now is not the time for Rhodes to get writer’s block because a   wants to headline WrestleMania. That’s just bad storytelling. Many are comparing Rhodes’ situation to the Daniel Bryan story. While there are similarities, this is worse. Much worse. In 2014, WWE didn’t have Daniel Bryan figured into its WrestleMania plans at all. Bryan wasn’t even included in the 2014 Royal Rumble, so the “Yes Movement” became an organic groundswell of support for Bryan, which ultimately became undeniable. In Rhodes’ case, WWE has trained its fans to believe that Cody is finishing his story. Even after Rhodes shockingly failed to defeat Reigns at WrestleMania 39, fans remained in support of the American Nightmare, knowing he’d finish his story at WrestleMania 40. With WWE now balking at the finish line, it is in danger of ruining one of its best modern-day storylines. The fallout could be disastrous, with fans likely to turn on Rhodes—not to mention Philadelphia turning on the WrestleMania 40 main event between  A   suggested WWE could be planning to unify the belts at SummerSlam, with presumed WWE world heavyweight champion Rhodes competing against whomever the WWE Undisputed Universal champion is coming out of WrestleMania. This is a terrible idea. Through Reigns’ scathing promo on SmackDown, WWE already defined the WWE World Heavyweight Championship as a second-place world title.   When Rollins was begging Rhodes to challenge him for the WWE World Championship on Raw, fans chanted “no!” As evidenced by CM Punk and Rollins himself, injuries can happen between now and SummerSlam. Most importantly, by then the bloom may be off the rose for Cody Rhodes’ story.

title: Jusuf Nurkic Has Been A Welcome Fit With The Phoenix Suns’ Big 3
content: The Phoenix Suns acquired Jusuf Nurkic and Grayson Allen in a cost-effective trade that has worked  The Phoenix Suns followed one big splash with another when they committed about $475 million to Kevin Durant and Bradley Beal in recent trades, but their most cost-effective deal has largely slipped under the national radar. Not only did the Suns acquire starting center Jusuf Nurkic and starting wing Grayson Allen for center Deandre Ayton from Portland in the three-team trade that also sent Trail Blazers’ guard Damian Lillard to Milwaukee two days before the start of training camp, they  Nurkic and Allen were instrumental in helping the Suns play through the early-season injury absences of Durant, Devin Booker and Beal, who have started together in only 18 of the Suns’ first 46 games. Nurkic, a 7-footer, has provided the physical presence in the paint on both ends of the floor that the Suns were unable to coax out of Ayton in his five seasons in Phoenix. “‘Nurk’ has been wonderful,” Suns coach Frank Vogel said. “I couldn’t speak loudly enough about the role he has played. The guy is doing what is asked of him, without the need to get more shots or more touches or anything like that.” Nurkic has received  and 10.3 rebounds in 45 games and is on pace for his fifth career double-double season, but it more his rebounding/passing/court awareness that has made him a good fit. Ayton, the first overall pick in the 2018 draft, recently told reporters in Portland that he has “nothing to prove in this league. I’m a max player, and I’ll continue to be a max player,” he said, apparently equating salary with productivity. Suns' center Jusuf Nurkic bangs with Indiana Pacers' big man Jalen Smith. (AP Photo/Matt York) The Suns did not always see it that way. Ayton, also 7-0, averaged a double-double in Phoenix and showed a nice shooting touch from the foul line in, especially when he and Chris Paul perfected their two-man game. Yet Ayton was seldom a physical presence inside, often out-rebounded by shorter but more aggressive players such as Montrezl Harrell. On a team with 20-point scorers Durant, Beal and Booker, Ayton’s point production became superfluous this season. A different complementary component was required. Ayton was was benched in the playoffs two years ago for inattentiveness on defense, and his deficiencies also seemed to alienate teammates. That the Nurkic trade was a money-saver for owner Mat Ishiba only made it that much more valuable. The Suns took on about $93.7 million in salary in adding Nurkic, Allen, forward Nassir Little and guard Keon Johnson, but they were able to get out from under   max contract that runs through 2025-26. Nurkic has two years and $37 million remaining on his four-year deal. “High IQ,” Bulls coach Billy Donovan said in evaluating Nurkic. “With the attention that those three (Durant, Booker, Beal) get, he’s a guy that is really good in the pocket. Over his time in his career he’s stretched his range to three-point range. And obviously, he’s a handful on the glass. He’s really good offensive rebounder.” Nurkic has contributed in multiple ways. He played a particularly physical game against Denver center and 2023 MVP Nikola Jokic on Dec.1, with 31 points and 11 rebounds. Nurkic and Jokic went body-to-body on three consecutive paint possessions in the third quarter and Nurkic scored on a pair of inside moves. The Nuggets won, 119-111, but the Suns noticed. “Just playing basketball,” Nurkic said. “Trying to use my strength, and trying to be who I am as big as I am.” Jusuf Nurkic has been an effective distributor in his first season in Phoenix. (Photo by Michael  Nurkic also flashed to the right spot when a Suns’ side inbounds play broke down in the final seconds of a 115-113 victory over the Chicago Bulls on Jan. 22. He took the inbounds pass when Durant was covered and deftly threw a quick bounce-pass back to Durant, who made a game-winning, double-clutch jump shot. “Probably a guy who doesn’t get enough credit for his passing,” Donovan said. “He plays in the middle of the floor and he has really good vision. He connects a lot on the second (weak) side and really generates shots for guys, because with Durant and Beal and Booker, when you send two on the ball and the ball gets into the pocket for him, he is really a very, very good playmaker from there.” Nurkic is not always on the floor late in games. The Suns have used small lineups when matchups dictate, such as in the 119-117 victory over Sacramento on Jan. 16 and a 118-105 victory over Miami last week. In those games, 6-11 Durant moved up to cover the opposing big, and the switch enables the Suns to put five shooters on the floor. The Suns have worked the matchup the other way, also. Nurkic had 28 points, 11 rebounds and six assists in 30 minutes in a 136-120 victory over the Brooklyn Nets last Wednesday, diving to the basket against over-matched Nic Clayton inside. Vogel, known as a defensive-mind coach, has been pleased with Nurkic’s play on that end. “He has really grown defensively from the standpoint of attacking everything that comes to our basket,” Vogel said. “Rim protection is as much as mindset as a talent, and I think he has really grown with that. “He’s had some opportunities in games where he hasn’t had opportunities to score or to facilitate, and some games he doesn’t touch the ball as much. He just goes out, feels the game out, and plays around the other guys. That type of unselfishness should not go unnoticed. We’re really pleased with what he’s brought to the table.” Jusuf Nurkic has provided a defensive presence in the paint. (AP Photo/Ross D. Franklin)

title: Xavi: FC Barcelona Is ‘Paying For Caso Negreira’ After Alaves Win
content: Xavi Hernandez believes that FC Barcelona is being punished for the Caso Negreira scandal.  FC Barcelona head coach Xavi Hernandez said that FC Barcelona is "paying" for the Caso Negreira furore following a 3-1 win over Alaves on Saturday. The Blaugrana went 2-0 up thanks to goals from Robert Lewandowski and Ilkay Gundogan. Samu Omorodion pulled a consolation back two minutes after the German doubled the visitors' lead, but Vitor Roque then helped Barca retain a comfortable cushion that was enough to seal three points. Vitor Roque thankfully didn't become the villain of the night following his red card for a pair of yellows. Reacting to the bizarre sending off when it appeared as though the Brazilian didn't even touch a defender he was deemed to have fouled, Xavi  : "It's another mistake by the referees against us. It's an injustice. You've all seen it." "I'm just asking that they let us compete. I'm not going to talk about the referees anymore. Today is another glaring mistake. We are paying for the Negreira case. But I'm not going to talk about the referees. You can see the reality. I don't say it anymore or you'll kill me. Another mistake, again," he added. Barca was charged for continued corruption in the sports field last year for paying the former vice president of the Technical Referees Committee over $7.5 million from 2001 to 2018. The club denies wrongdoing and insists that the payments were made for honest consultation work, with the investigation continuing into 2024. Xavi praised his new striker Vitor Roque, who joined from Athletico Paranaense last month, for his eye for goal, the way he arrives in the box, and the depth he offers. There were also compliments for right winger Lamine Yamal, who played his part in Vitor Roque's second strike in two games. "He's a beastly talent. [At just] 16 years old. Very few appear in these conditions. How he works, how he helps the full-back," Xavi said of the prodigy, who is already a starter and "has no ceiling". "We've made a specific plan with him. He's a difference maker. We are looking at something special. I highlight how he competes, he doesn't get tired. "He does many kilometers at high intensity. He comes back to defend. I am very happy. He's got defensive humility," Xavi beamed.

title: Ozempic Maker Novo Nordisk Beats Profit Forecasts As Weight-Loss Sales Soar
content: Danish pharma giant Novo Nordisk on Wednesday reported better-than-expected earnings for 2023, propelled by a tsunami of demand for its blockbuster weight loss and diabetes drugs as new treatments emerge and compete for a slice of the growing market. Sales of Wegovy, an injectable prescription weight loss medicine, has helped boost profits for Novo  Novo Nordisk reported $33.7 billion of sales for 2023, an increase of 36% at constant exchange rates and beating analysts’ expectations. Full-year operating profit also exceeded analysts’ expectations, climbing 44% at constant exchange rates to $15 billion. Diluted earnings per share rose 52% to 18.61 Danish kroner ($2.7). Around 90% of the drugmaker's overall sales—$31.2 billion—came from its obesity and diabetes care division, which includes Ozempic and Wegovy, respectively authorized to treat diabetes and obesity. Sales of GLP-1 diabetes medications—a class that includes Ozempic—and in obesity care were largely responsible for this uptick, Novo Nordisk said, rising 52% and 154% at constant exchange rates, respectively. Novo Nordisk shares rose around 4% during early trading on Wednesday morning. "We are very pleased with the strong performance in 2023 reflecting that more than 40 million people are now benefiting from our innovative diabetes and obesity treatments,” said CEO Lars Fruergaard Jorgensen. “Our focus in 2024 will be on reaching more patients, progressing and expanding our pipeline as well as the continued significant expansion of our production capacity." The stellar success of Ozempic and Wegovy—both branded drugs containing the same active ingredient, semaglutide—has rapidly propelled Novo Nordisk into a rarified club of extraordinarily valuable companies and triggered an acknowledged   for a company of its size. It now has a market value of around $480 billion, up from around $310 billion at the start of 2023, $250 billion at the start of 2022 and around $160 billion at the start of 2021. With such fast growth, Novo Nordisk recently dethroned French luxury goods firm LVMH as Europe’s most valuable public company and its market value is larger than the annual economic output of its home country, Denmark. Officials there are  over the country’s reliance on a single firm and   into the same trap as Finland when it hitched its wagon to erstwhile phone giant  . Semaglutide mimics the action of a hormone—GLP-1—that is responsible for regulating appetite and blood sugar. It has been shown to help facilitate weight loss and studies suggest it could bestow other health benefits in areas like heart and kidney disease as well. While it is far from the first drug shown to reduce weight, it does not appear to be accompanied by the same litany of often serious side effects as previous generations of weight loss drugs. Experts have therefore hailed it as a breakthrough in the fight against obesity, one of our era’s most pressing public health problems. For several years, Novo Nordisk has been the sole provider of GLP-1 generation of weight loss drugs and it has heavily struggled to meet booming demand. It was recently   by Eli Lilly, whose Zepbound injections—a branded name for tirzepatide, the same ingredient in its diabetes drug Mounjaro—are also expected to become bestsellers. Analysts believe the anti-obesity market could become one of the most lucrative opportunities for the pharmaceutical sector in its history and could   be worth as much as $100 billion by the end of the decade and   much more. Adjacent industries like wellness,  , and fitness are reportedly   the popularity of weight loss drugs will eat into revenues. Novo Nordisk said it expects solid growth for the year ahead as well, with sales expected to climb as much as 26% and operating profit as much as 29% at constant exchange rates.  (FT)

title: Instead of Attacking Mark Zuckerberg, Parents Should Be Thanking Him
content: School drop-off in modern times is a bit of a marvel. To a substantial degree, parents from the 20  century wouldn’t recognize it. Think about it. So many fathers leaving their kids at the front door, or inside the classroom. Better yet, so many   participating in drop-off together. This isn’t how it used to be, and readers know why. Or they should. In the days before 24-hour connectivity care of the Internet, work took place at a specific location. In my case, while I never saw my father on weekday mornings in the 1970s and 80s, my kids see me every weekday morning right up to school drop-off. And this in no way makes me unique. It was impossible not to think of modern parental realities while reading about the obnoxious grilling that Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg and other prominent technology types suffered at the hands of grandstanding politicians (a redundancy, no doubt) the other day. Take Sen. Lindsey Graham. According to the ankle-biter from South Carolina, Zuckerberg and others “have blood” on their hands. It’s probably too late for the 68-year old in Graham, but he needs to grow up. What is the source of the angst manufactured by Graham and his fellow political alarmists (yet another redundancy) including Sens. Josh Hawley and Richard Durbin? They’re tying sexual exploitation, suicide, and all manner of other youthful societal maladies to the proliferation of “social media.” That’s right, before Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, Snapchat, TikTok, and myriad other fruits of technological advance, young people were well-adjusted, healthy, and happy owing to life bereft of internet. Oh boy, weren’t the good old days great? Those of us who entered our teen years in the ‘80s, ‘90s and ‘00s surely never had friends who were sent into drug and alcohol rehab, never experienced sexual exploitation or heard about it (it turns out NBC’s   was just fiction!), never were exposed to or thought about suicide, and surely never had cross words with our parents. Ok, maybe the latter was true, but mainly because in the days before constant connectivity care of the internet and manifestations of same, more than a few of us rarely saw our parents as is. Seriously, what the parents of old would give for today’s problems! Kids spending lots of time on Facebook, Instagram and other popular social media sites. How very quaint considering the fears of old. In my day Angel Dust and cocaine kept parents up at night, as did television movies like   meant to terrify always-at-the-office parents about sexual predators who were seemingly not at the office when they were. But wait, social media and the endless stream of photos on Facebook and the rest body shame the youth of today on the way to bulimia and anorexia nervosa! Except that we had those fears too. Think 1981, and Jennifer Jason Leigh in  . Also, wasn’t recently collapsed   the annual whipping boy of old on the matter of body-shaming, bulimia, and countless other psychological problems of the body kind thanks to its swimsuit issue? Seemingly lost on the perpetually alarmed and offended is that teen angst has been around as long as teenagers have been, meaning  . From there, hopefully the reasonable among us can acknowledge that as opposed to being the problem for teens and young people, Facebook and others are the solution. Again, what parents of old would have given for the worries of today whereby interest in smartphones and the countless apps on same means that parents can not only regulate to varying degrees what their kids are seeing and doing, they also know   their kids are as they’re tapping away. This was a luxury parents of old didn’t have, among many others. Which brings us back to school drop-off. Thanks to the internet-authored connectivity that more and more enables remote work in concert with global marketing plans hatched on Facebook, Instagram and TikTok from homes masquerading as corporate headquarters, more and more parents are capable of closely looking after their kids at all hours as a way of protecting them from the endless threats that parents formerly couldn’t police from their actual offices. Yes, rather than attacking Mark Zuckerberg and colleagues, parents and hapless politicians should be thanking them.

title: 2024’s Tech Layoffs: Block, PayPal, iRobot, eBay Cut Hundreds Of Jobs
content: Identity security company Okta told its staff on Thursday it will cut as many as 400 employees, while Zoom reportedly plans to slash 150 positions—the latest in a string of job cuts this year that have rocked the tech industry, including at Microsoft, Amazon, eBay and PayPal, following a   in 2022 and 2023. Zoom will reportedly lay off 150 employees.  CEO Todd McKinnon announced in a Securities and Exchange Commission   that the identity management company will reduce its head count by roughly 400 employees (7% of its workforce), acknowledging the “reality is that costs are still too high.” , whose popularity exploded as remote meetings took off during the Covid-19 pandemic, will cut 150 employees, sources told  , a reduction of less than 2% of its workforce and its   of layoffs in under a year, after the company let go of another 15% of its workforce last February—Zoom told Forbes the company “regularly evaluate[s] , the provider of email and data security tools, said it expects to cut 280 employees, saying the layoffs are part of a “forward-looking” strategy aimed at positioning the company “for continued and long-term success.” , a payment firm headed by Twitter co-founder Jack Dorsey, implemented a round of layoffs the company announced late last year, affecting a targeted 1,000 of the company’s roughly 13,000 employees,     reported.  plans to reduce its head count by   over the next 12 months, according to an internal memo obtained by  , reducing the San-Francisco-Bay-area firm’s staff by roughly 9% in an effort to “right-size” the company.    Monday it will cut roughly 350 jobs, after calling off plans for an acquisition by Amazon originally valued at $1.7 billion—iRobot’s latest layoffs come after the Massachusetts-based company   140 employees in August 2022. After cutting a whopping   last winter,   announced plans last week to cut another   (roughly 8% of its workforce) in its videogame divisions—including at Xbox and Activision Blizzard, the videogame company Microsoft acquired in a massive $68.7 billion deal late last year—in an effort to promote a “sustainable cost structure,” according to Microsoft Gaming CEO Phil Spencer. Online retailer  —which   500 employees last February—reduced its headcount by 1,000 employees (roughly 9% of its workforce), with CEO Jamie Iannone lamenting in a   that the company’s expenses “outpaced the growth of our business.” San Francisco tech giant   will also conduct a major layoff affecting roughly 700 employees, or 1% of its workforce, sources told the  , just over a year after the company cut 7,900 employees, which CEO Marc Benioff   to a “challenging” economic environment. After   1,750 employees last year,   CEO Niraj Shah   earlier this month that the company will slash 1,650 jobs in an effort to “position the company both now and over the long term,” one week after Shah   employees to work “long hours.”  also laid out plans this week to cut 2,350 jobs and close five department stores, affecting roughly 13% of its corporate staff and 3.5% of its total workforce, according to an internal memo obtained by the  .  plans to cut employees across its global advertising and sales teams, the company confirmed in a statement to Forbes, one week after it laid off “hundreds” more employees across several divisions, including its engineering and hardware teams, as well as employees developing its voice-operated virtual assistant, Google Assistant, according to an internal email obtained by the   and  . , a live streaming site owned by Amazon, announced plans to cut 35% of its staff (roughly 500 employees), CEO Dan Clancy   in a blog post last Wednesday, saying Twitch has “work to do to rightsize” the company, calling it “meaningfully larger than it needs to be given the size of our business,” while Amazon’s audiobook division Audible also   a round of cuts affecting 100 employees. That same day,   announced plans to cut “several hundred” employees at its Prime Video and MGM Studios divisions, following a review of “nearly every aspect” of the company’s business operations, according to a memo obtained by   from Mike Hopkins, the senior vice president of Prime Video. Language learning app   earlier this month slashed 10% of its contract employees (it’s not immediately clear how many workers this affects), as the company pivots toward relying on artificial intelligence for content generation,     reported, though the company said none of its full-time employees would be affected by the layoffs.  CEO Jason Citron announced the platform will cut 17% of its workforce (roughly 170 employees) to “sharpen [its] focus and improve the way [it] work[s] together to bring more agility” to the company,   reported. Video game software developer   announced in a   it will cut one-quarter of its staff (roughly 1,800 jobs) as part of a restructuring plan to “position itself for long-term and profitable growth.” Layoffs in January hit a  , with more than 82,300 employees losing their jobs at U.S. companies, according to a report released Thursday by Challenger, Gray & Christmas. With a group of tech giants and startups, as well as banks and financial service companies all conducting job cuts, the month of January saw the second-most layoffs in any month since January 2009 (nearly 103,000 people lost their jobs in January 2023). . That’s how many employees lost their jobs in major U.S. layoffs last year, according to Forbes’ layoff tracker, which included layoffs affecting 100 or more jobs. The biggest of those cuts came in July, when now-bankrupt trucking company Yellow laid off all 30,000 of its employees. Preceding Yellow Corporation were a pack of tech and manufacturing companies announcing layoffs, including  , which announced plans in January 2023 to cut 8,000 employees amid an “uncertain economy,” and laid off another 9,000 workers in November, after cutting 10,000 jobs in late 2022. Google parent   cut another 12,000 employees in January 2023 due to what CEO Sundar Pichai called “tough choices,” while   and Microsoft each laid off 10,000 positions that same month (Meta cut another 6,000 employees two months later). Banking giant Citigroup announced earlier this month it will cut 20,000 employees over the next two years, according to a statement from CFO Mark Mason, following a $1.8 billion fourth quarter   the bank’s worst quarter in 15 years. Citigroup’s cuts follow a   at major U.S. banks, following investment banking firm Goldman Sachs, which cut 4,000 employees last year, and JPMorgan Chase, which let go of 1,000 employees in May.  (Forbes)  (Forbes)  (Forbes)

title: Jet Door Blown Off Alaska Airlines Plane Is Found In Oregon Schoolteacher’s Backyard
content: A schoolteacher in Oregon has found a “key missing component” from the Alaska Airlines jet that blew open mid-flight last week, the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB)   Sunday, an important step towards understanding what happened as U.S. airlines   dozens of aircraft over safety concerns. An Alaska Airlines Boeing 737 MAX 9 plane sits at a gate at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport in  A Portland schoolteacher has found the missing door plug from the Boeing 737 Max 9 jet forced to make an   after a dramatic in-flight blowout last Friday, NTSB chair Jennifer Homendy said at a press conference late on Sunday. The teacher, identified only as Bob, found the missing fuselage in his yard and contacted the agency with pictures. “Thank you, Bob,” Homendy said, adding that investigators are “really pleased” with the finding. Homendy said investigators are going to go and pick up the component and “make sure that we begin analyzing it.” A  , which   has a window and weighs around 27kg (60lb), is used to seal an emergency exit that is not used by the airline. Investigators hope analyzing the piece will give an insight into what happened when the plug detached from the aircraft over Oregon, blowing a refrigerator-sized hole in the side of the plane. Investigators have been searching for the missing door plug—  as a “key missing component”—since the  of Alaska Airlines Flight 1282 in Portland shortly after takeoff on Friday. The flight, which was carrying 177 passengers and crew, suffered an accident that prompted panic as oxygen masks descended and the cabin depressurized,   with such force that headrests and cushions were ripped from seats. No one was hurt in the incident, thanks to passengers wearing seat belts for takeoff, the plane having not yet reached cruising altitude—which would have been much higher and would’ve led to a more forceful depressurization—and nobody sitting in the seats immediately next to the plug that blew off. The incident follows a   of   for Boeing and its 737 Max jet and the company has faced heavy   for its conduct. Its entire fleet was previously grounded for more than a year for safety checks after the loss of two aircraft in fatal crashes and numerous other faults and quality   have been found since, including calls for airlines to check the rudder for a missing bolt in December. U.S. regulators have now   the craft pending further safety inspections. The vast majority of Boeing 737 Max 9s are   by U.S. airlines, mostly United Airlines and Alaska. They are also used by Turkish Airlines, Panama’s Copa Airlines and Aeromexico, who have all reportedly grounded jets for inspections. The directive has sparked cancellations in the U.S. affecting tens of thousands of people. "Safety is our top priority and we deeply regret the impact this event has had on our customers and their passengers,” Boeing said in a statement in response to the latest grounding,   to CNN. “We agree with and fully support the FAA’s decision to require immediate inspections of 737-9 airplanes with the same configuration as the affected airplane." 171. That’s how   Boeing 737 Max jets the Federal Aviation Administration has   pending safety inspections, r , 215,000 are configured to use the plug. The U.K.'s aviation regulator has also   inspections before the aircraft enter the country’s airspace and the EU   the FAA’s directive.  (Forbes)  (AP News)

title: Russia Has Massed 500 Tanks For An Attack On Kupyansk
content: The Ukrainian 4th Tank Brigade in 2023. Five hundred tanks. More than 600 fighting vehicles. Hundreds of howitzers. Forty thousand troops. According to Ukraine’s eastern command, Russia has assembled a huge field army in eastern Ukraine opposite the free Ukrainian city of Kupyansk. It’s obvious what this army aims to do: retake a huge swathe of Kharkiv Oblast that the Russians briefly occupied in 2022—until a powerful Ukrainian counteroffensive liberated most of the oblast late that year. Everything east of the nearest major river is the goal. “The Russian Federation plans to seize the entire Donetsk and Luhansk Oblasts and part of Kharkiv Oblast up to the Oskil River by March 2024,” the Ukrainian Center for Defense Strategies  . The river threads through Kupyansk from the north. Why March? Because that’s when Russia will “vote” for “president” in a national “election.” In fact, Vladimir Putin is the only real candidate—and will maintain his brutal, dictatorial control over Russia  the Russian war of aggression in Ukraine. A slice of Kharkiv would be an election-day gift to Putin from the Russian army in Ukraine. Some or part of around 10 Ukrainian brigades, anchored in the north by the 3rd Tank Brigade and south by the 4th Tank Brigade, defends Kupyansk and surrounding settlements. It’s a significant forces with perhaps 20,000 troops and hundreds of tanks, fighting vehicles and howitzers. But people and vehicles aren’t the problem for the Ukrainians. The problem is  . The United States was one of the biggest donors of 155-millimeter shells for Ukraine’s best big guns—and pro-Russia Republicans in the U.S. Congress cut off aid to Ukraine last fall. Since then, Ukrainian forces’ daily allotment of shells has fallen by two-thirds to just 2,000 rounds. Russian forces meanwhile fire as many as 10,000 shells a day, thanks to a steady supply of ammo from North Korea. Russia’s new firepower advantage allows it to concentrate artillery without much fear of Ukrainian counterbattery fire— . “This situation empowers Russia to execute a well-known approach: the systematic destruction of urban areas, rendering them indefensible,” Ukrainian analysis team Frontelligence Insight  . The demolition already has begun. “Our satellite imagery reveals sustained and intense artillery damage” around Kupyansk, Frontelligence Insight reported. “Artillery shortages and delays in Western security assistance will create uncertainty in Ukrainian operational plans,” the Institute for the Study of War in Washington, D.C.  , “and likely prompt Ukrainian forces to husband materiel, which may force Ukrainian forces to make tough decisions about prioritizing certain sectors of the front over sectors where limited territorial setbacks are least damaging.” It’s not clear whether Kyiv is willing to trade away any of Kharkiv Oblast. With a pre-war population of 1.4 million, Kharkiv is Ukraine’s third city—and hosts strategic war industries including Ukraine’s main tank plant. So the Kupyansk garrison must hold. Anticipating the coming offensive, the Ukrainian defense ministry has organized new mechanized brigades and deployed them to Kupyansk to reinforce the garrison.  Perhaps most importantly, Ukrainian workshops are building explosives-laden first-person-view drones—tens of thousands of them per month. As artillery ammunition becomes scarce, Ukrainian brigades are flinging more and more FPVs at the Russians: sometimes thousands per day all along the 600-mile front. But the FPVs range just two miles or so—too short to target artillery that might be 15 or miles from the line of contact. Drone-operators have made quick work of small Russian assault groups that, for months now, have been probing the Kupyansk sector. But can a swarm of two-pound drones, even thousands of them, defeat 500 tanks and 650 fighting vehicles as they attack behind a wall of artillery fire? We may find out.

title: ‘Bitcoin Vs. The Dollar’—Biden Administration Suddenly Declares U.S. Crypto ‘Emergency’ After Huge Price Surge
content: Bitcoin  and crypto have surged back after a devastating price crash ( ). The bitcoin price has topped $43,000 per bitcoin, up around 200% from its recent lows of $15,000,  Now,  , U.S. president Joe Biden's administration has issued an "emergency collection of data request" to those that secure the bitcoin network—fanning the flames of a battle some see as bitcoin against the U.S. dollar. — The U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA), under president Joe Biden, has launched an  The Biden government this week signed off an emergency probe into how much power bitcoin and crypto miners are using, with the Energy Information Administration (EIA) set to begin the urgent collection of data this coming week. Bitcoin miners, who use high-powered computers to verify transactions and maintain bitcoin's blockchain in return for newly minted coins, will be required to respond with their energy use details, as part of an emergency data collection request authorized by the Office of Management and Budget on January 26. "We intend to continue to analyze and write about the energy implications of cryptocurrency mining activities in the United States," EIA Administrator Joe DeCarolis   in a statement. "We will specifically focus on how the energy demand for cryptocurrency mining is evolving, identify geographic areas of high growth, and quantify the sources of electricity used to meet cryptocurrency mining demand." The EIA pointed to the possibility of "public harm" from bitcoin and mining for the need to collect the data. The bitcoin mining industry has been criticized for its eye-watering energy usage, which studies have found could be as much each year as some small countries. "Recognizing that this emergency collection is experimental and provisional with the understood intention that EIA wants to build to a new standard collection," the OMB   in its approval. The emergency survey has sparked fears among the bitcoin and crypto community that long-held fears of a broad government crackdown on the bitcoin mining industry could be beginning. Last year, Florida governor and former U.S. presidential hopeful Ron DeSantis warned  . "[The] EIA's latest move to mandate bitcoin mining firms to disclose their energy usage is a direct targeting of the digital asset sector," the Texas Blockchain Council  . The bitcoin price has rocketed back over the last year, boosting the wider crypto market, even as  "Biden has declared a Federal 'emergency' because bitcoin is winning," Pierre Rochard, head of research at Colorado-based bitcoin miner Riot Platforms,   to X,  : "the $3 trillion deficit, $34 trillion debt, and insolvent fiat banking system" could be considered an "emergency." The huge increase in the supply of U.S. dollars and U.S. debt through the Covid pandemic and lockdowns has galvanized bitcoin supporters who fear the collapse of the U.S. dollar is imminent. "Over the last ten years, all fiat has declined against the dollar, even as the dollar has collapsed against bitcoin," tech investor and former Coinbase  chief technology investor Balaji Srinivasan   to X. "Biden vs Trump is the American election. Bitcoin vs dollar is the internet election. Which is truly more important? The election doesn’t matter as much if they lose the printer. Just one or two more orders of magnitude, and that will be clear."

title: Eagle Pass: Here’s What To Know About Texas’ Standoff With Border Patrol
content: The Texas National Guard seized control of a park in Eagle Pass, Texas, this week and is denying access to Border Patrol agents as the state continues to try and wrestle border enforcement away from the Biden Administration, whose immigration policies have been a frequent target of Gov. Greg Abbott. FILE - Texas troopers stand near a "No Trespassing" sign and concertina wire along the banks of the  On Thursday, Rolando Salinas, mayor of Eagle Pass,   outside Shelby Park of vehicles parked behind a fence, claiming that state officials had seized control of the park for border control operations—but Salinas alleged that the city did not agree to the seizure, claiming: “This is not something that we wanted, this is not something that we asked for as a city.” In a  to CBS News, a Texas Military Department spokesman said that the Guard has maintained a presence with security points at the park since 2021, but that they’re preparing “for future illegal immigrant surges and to restrict access to organizations that perpetuate illegal immigrant crossings” in Eagle Pass area” (Forbes has also contacted the Texas Military Department for comment). In a Friday  with the Supreme Court, the Department of Justice alleged that Border Patrol agents had been denied access to the area, which includes a boat ramp that agents typically use to conduct operations along the Rio Grande, with gates and “armed personnel” blocking normal access points. The Department of Justice is asking the court to intervene, noting that the state’s actions since the government filing “demonstrate an escalation of the state’s measures to block” Border Patrol duties. In a   on X, formerly Twitter, Abbott reposted a video of Shelby Park, writing that “as caravans of migrants are moving through Mexico toward the border, we are making clear that Texas will be a tough place to cross.” In its Friday filing, the Department of Justice cites a Dec. 19   from a U.S. Appeals Court that bars Border Patrol agents from destroying state-erected fencing—a decision that the Justice Department is currently appealing—from contributing to the lack of access to the area. The Justice Department has also  Texas over a controversial immigration law that gives state officials the authority to arrest migrants crossing the border illegally—enforcement that’s typically reserved for the federal government. As the number of migrants crossing the border continues to surge, Abbott and other Texas Republicans have criticized the Biden Administration’s response. Eagle Pass has been the focus of these debates in recent months,  to the Texas Tribune, which notes that in June, Salinas agreed to allow the state to declare Shelby Park private property so that state officials could arrest migrants for trespassing. But resident complaints prompted Salinas to support rescinding that decision. There have been conflicting messages on the impact of the seizure on Border Patrol operations. The Border Patrol Union—which has   the Biden Administration’s response to the border—  that the state’s actions would enhance Border Patrol operations by taking agents away from an area where many migrants “are simply surrendering” and allowing them to patrol areas with higher numbers of migrants “who attempt to escape arrest.” But in the Department of Justice court filing, Border Patrol Lead Field Coordinator Robert Danley testified that Border Patrol uses the now fenced-off area as a “pre-staging area” for migrant encounters, where Border Patrol engages in mobile intake of migrants and treats emergent medical or welfare needs. Because of Texas’ actions, “Border Patrol is being denied the opportunity to use the area for staging migrants in a safe location that allows for the optimal use of law enforcement resources.” 2.4 million. That’s how many times migrants were caught  , a number that the government says is the highest since at least 1960. Abbott was the target of backlash after comments he made in a radio interview last week resurfaced, where he   that Texas was doing everything it’s power to stop immigration, noting: “The only thing that we're not doing is we're not shooting people who come across the border, because of course, the Biden administration would charge us with murder.” State Democrats quickly denounced the comments as they came to light.

title: Max Allegri Confirms Injury Boosts Ahead Of Derby d’Italia
content: TURIN, ITALY - JANUARY 27: Head coach of Juventus Massimiliano Allegri looks on during the Serie A  Max Allegri was keen to play down talk of any heat between Juventus and Inter ahead of Sunday night’s Derby d’Italia. The Coach had been engaged in a   with the Nerazzurri, but in his pre-match press conference opted to praise his rivals. “We have great respect for Inter,” Allegri told reporters on Saturday. “They are the strongest side and the favorites for the Scudetto. External talk doesn't interest us, we have to think about what we can do. Football has many unexpected events and you have to keep your feet on the ground.” “Playing a match like this, just one point behind Inter, is a reward for these wonderful guys. Having said that, anything can happen tomorrow, as always in these type of games." Inter have a game in hand over Juve in addition to their one point advantage in the table, and Allegri was asked to name one player he admired from the opposition. FLORENCE, ITALY - JANUARY 28:  Marcus Thuram of FC Internazionale warms up ahead the Serie A TIM  “An Inter player that I've been impressed by? I'd say [Marcus] Thuram,” Allegri responded before once again opting to play down any talk of a title win. “When you play there is always something to lose. Our strength is working on our limits, and we are very committed to this. We are a cohesive group, with the desire to do important things: in the meantime, we need at least 20 points to reach the Champions League." "It will be a wonderful evening of sport, in front of a sold-out stadium. We know Inter's strength, but we are very good as well: it is a step on our journey, we have many more points to earn to reach our goal." "It won't be a decisive turning point for the championship, because two draws are not enough to change everything. The decisive points are earned along the way. Everyone's talking about tomorrow, but the boys just have to go onto the pitch calmly, have fun and do their best, knowing our limits, but also our good form." Federico Chiesa and Adrien Rabiot have been suffering with injuries of late, but the boss confirmed some good news about their return to action. "Tomorrow evening we will all travel to Milan: Chiesa and Rabiot have recovered, and we have the two new signings. [Carlos] Alcaraz will train with us today, so we'll see. TURIN, ITALY - FEBRUARY 1:  Newly signed Carlos Alcaraz arrives to join Juventus on February 1, 2024  "Alcaraz is eager to learn and do well, and is to be discovered; [Tiago] Djaló will be inserted slowly, as he is coming off a major injury.” “Chiesa always makes himself available and does his best, clearly his way of playing causes him some discomfort regarding the injury he had, he has to live with it, but time will help him." As Allegri was about to sign off, he also dropped a hint about the way Juve may approach the fixture. "What we need to do tomorrow? Run, a lot. In the reverse fixture it was very tactical and balanced, tomorrow it will be different." No matter how much Allegri attempts to play down the contest, all eyes will be on San Siro on Sunday evening to see if Juve can leapfrog Inter into top spot in the Serie A table.

title: Sixers' Joel Embiid Could Help Teammate Tyrese Maxey Earn An Extra $41 Million
content: PHILADELPHIA, PENNSYLVANIA - NOVEMBER 08: Joel Embiid #21 and Tyrese Maxey #0 of the Philadelphia  Philadelphia 76ers center Joel Embiid, the NBA's reigning Most Valuable Player, missed his 13th game of the season on Thursday with a meniscus injury that will sideline him at least through the weekend. ESPN's   reported that "there is still uncertainty over how Embiid and the 76ers will move forward with a treatment plan for the injury, and options will be discussed over the next several days." Either way, Embiid seems unlikely to return anytime soon. That's terrible news for the Sixers, but it could help teammate Tyrese Maxey earn a financial windfall this summer. The NBA's new CBA requires players to play in at least 65 games to become eligible for MVP, Defensive Player of the Year, Most Improved Player, the All-NBA teams and the All-Defensive teams. Players must play at least 20 minutes per game in all but two of those games, and they have to play between 15-20 minutes in the other two. Embiid, who was both the league's MVP and the first-team All-NBA center last season, is all but certain to fall short of that 65-game threshold this year. He isn't the only All-NBA member from last season in danger of missing out, either. Miami Heat forward Jimmy Butler, a second-team selection last year, has already missed 15 games this season. That means he can miss only two more before he becomes ineligible. New York Knicks forward Julius Randle, a third-team selection last year and an All-Star reserve this season, has missed the Knicks' past three games with a dislocated shoulder that seems likely to sideline him at least through the All-Star break. Indiana Pacers point guard Tyrese Haliburton didn't make an All-NBA team last season, but he was voted in as an All-Star starter this year. However, Haliburton has already missed 13 games this season and left 13 minutes into the Jan. 8 game against the Boston Celtics where he suffered the hamstring injury that plagued him for the rest of the month. According to   of Fieldhouse Files, the in-season tournament title game does count toward Haliburton's number of games played. That means he can miss four more before becoming ineligible for All-NBA. Since his return, he's barely cracking 20 minutes per game, which suggests he and the Pacers have the 65-game minimum in mind. With Embiid, Haliburton, Butler and Randle all in danger of becoming ineligible for All-NBA and the other major awards, that could open more spots for other players. Maxey, who was named an All-Star for the first time on Thursday, might be uniquely poised to benefit. In Embiid's absence Thursday against the Utah Jazz, Maxey scored a career-high 51 points on 17-of-27 shooting. He became the   in the past 45-plus years to record 50-plus points in zero turnovers in a game, trailing only Boston Celtics forward Jayson Tatum. The Sixers might not need  level of production out of him every night, but he needs to be their offensive engine until Embiid returns. Maxey is already averaging a career-high 26.3 points and 6.4 assists per game, albeit in a league-leading 37.5 minutes per night. If he has an uptick in production sans Embiid and keeps the Sixers afloat in the playoff race, voters might look favorably upon his All-NBA case at the end of the season. The All-NBA teams used to be divided by position—two guards, two forwards and one center on each of the three teams—but the new CBA made them positionless. That could help Maxey if there are more than six guards deserving of All-NBA honors, but it could work against him if more forwards and bigs have better cases than some of the guards. The Sixers   on signing Maxey to an extension this past offseason to keep his cheap $13.0 million cap hold on their books for this summer. Leading up to the trade deadline, they have the ability to create   in cap space this summer by renouncing all of their free agents, including Tobias Harris, De'Anthony Melton and Nicolas Batum. But that flexibility could prove costly when it comes to Maxey. If Maxey makes an All-NBA team, he'll become eligible for a max contract that begins at 30 percent of the salary cap instead of 25 percent. Based on the  , the 30 percent max would start at $42.3 million and be worth $245.3 million over five years, while a 25 percent max would start at $35.25 million and be worth $204.5 million. From a team perspective, it would benefit the Sixers if Maxey falls short of an All-NBA team. It won't affect their offseason plans either way—they'll re-sign him after making their other moves if they dip below the salary cap—but that $7 million-per-year difference could limit their flexibility in future years. There's nothing they can do about that now, though. They need to lean on Maxey until Embiid returns, which means his production is likely to spike. The Sixers' final place in the standings could help determine whether Maxey makes an All-NBA team or not. If he does, he’ll likely have an extra $41 million headed his way this offseason, in part thanks to Embiid.

title: Since The Brewers Traded Corbin Burnes, The NL Central Is Up For Grabs
content: Cincinnati Reds' Elly De La Cruz steals home with Milwaukee Brewers catcher William Contreras  The National League Central is one of the most turbulent divisions in MLB. It always seems to have three or four clubs who are above average without ever having one of the best in the league, leading to frenetic Septembers with constantly shifting standings. Also, there are the Pittsburgh Pirates. 2023 was even more chaotic than usual as the Milwaukee Brewers eventually pulled away with 92 wins, the Chicago Cubs and Cincinnati Reds both surprised the league by finishing above .500, and the St. Louis Cardinals landed in last place for the first time since 1990. The Brewers were favored to repeat as division champs for the first time since 1981-1982... until they   in a shocking move two days ago, then announced they’re “ .” Now the division is wide open, but there are still an unusually high number of impact free agents available. Each of the five franchises has a path to the NL Central crown if they act quickly to fill their needs. The youth movement is here in Milwaukee, for better or worse.   this offseason before he ever played a game in MLB. He’ll be joined in the starting lineup by William Contreras, Sal Frelick, Garrett Mitchell, Joey Ortiz, and Brice Turang, all of whom have yet to reach their arbitration-eligible years. Christian Yelich is still kicking around and they signed Rhys Hoskins to man first base. Willy Adames, the dependable, power-hitting shortstop, appears to be the odd man out. He has one year remaining before free agency. If the club can get MLB-ready starting pitching in a trade for him, they have to listen. With Burnes gone, the rotation gets sparse after Freddy Peralta. Alternatively, they could even consider moving Jeferson Quero for pitching. He’s one of the game’s best catching prospects, but he won’t help the club immediately and is blocked by Contreras anyway. The big question of the Cubs’ offseason is whether or not they’ll re-sign Cody Bellinger. The best position player in this year’s free-agent class remains on the market, but the team could be content to move on. Future Gold Glover Pete Crow-Armstrong is ready to take over in center field, Ian Happ and Seiya Suzuki will man the corners, recent acquisition Michael Busch will play first base, and Christopher Morel is the primary designated hitter. If they do bring Bellinger back, they’d have to make a corresponding trade just to make the pieces fit. If they’re going to give out another long-term contract in the ballpark of $30 million per season, they might be better off signing a pitcher instead. Left-handers Blake Snell and Jordan Montgomery are still unsigned. They brought in Japanese free agent Shota Imanaga to fill Marcus Stroman’s void, but aging starters Kyle Hendricks and Jameson Taillon are less than reliable, and Imanaga himself is still unproven. Signing one of the best starters available when Milwaukee expelled their ace could shift the balance of power in the division. Many people thought the Reds would deal away their glut of infielders to clear playing time for their youngsters and supplement other needs this winter. Instead, they signed corner infielder Jeimer Candelario to a three-year, $36 million contract, exacerbating the logjam. Elly De La Cruz, Christian Encarnacion-Strand, Noelvi Marte, and Matt McLain all debuted in 2023 and deserve regular at bats. Jonathan India remains on the roster against all odds, but is a prime candidate to be traded. On the pitching side, the team signed Nick Martinez and Frankie Montas to join homegrown starters Andrew Abbott, Graham Ashcraft, and Hunter Greene. The bullpen is a greater concern, even after acquiring free agents Emilio Pagán and Brent Suter. With the relief pitching market thinned out in free agency, they could see if they can move India or Encarnacion-Strand for reliable relievers. The Pirates won 76 games last year and finished in fourth place. That constitutes a relative success for one of MLB’s most moribund franchises. Would they be better off if they sprung for Snell or Bellinger? Of course, but owner Bob Nutting is more likely to sell you one of the city’s lovely bridges. Their best bet for success is hoping that young post-prospects like Oneil Cruz and Henry Davis take leaps forward. Their 2024 season—and their hopes for the future—rest on the right arm of Paul Skenes, the consensus top pitching prospect in MLB. He was the first overall pick in the 2023 draft after dominating college baseball at LSU. He arguably possesses the best fastball   the best slider in the minors and commands both of them well. He doesn’t have anything left to prove at the minor-league level, so it’s just a question of when the Pirates want to start his service clock. The Cardinals are learning the difference between “multipositional” and “positionless.” Brendan Donovan and Tommy Edman represent the former, but neither is a complete player offensively. Nolan Gorman and Jordan Walker are the latter. Even though both have enormous power potential, they need to take major steps forward with their glovework to avoid dragging the team down. On the other side of that coin is shortstop Masyn Winn, a potentially elite defender who still needs to prove he can hit MLB pitching. Despite all of the question marks in the lineup, their pitching was the main reason they lost 91 games. They attempted to shore up their rotation early in the offseason by signing Cy Young runner-up Sonny Gray and veteran inning-eaters Kyle Gibson and Lance Lynn, but at 34, 36, and 36, those moves could easily backfire.   and they should inquire about a reunion with Montgomery.

title: WWE SmackDown Results: Winners And Grades As The Rock Returns
content: Cody Rhodes will come face-to-face with Roman Reigns on SmackDown. Tonight’s broadcast of a sold-out SmackDown in Birmingham, AL featured Roman Reigns coming face-to-face with Cody Rhodes for the first time since Rhodes won his second Royal Rumble match. While Seth Rollins made a compelling case for Rhodes to challenge him at WrestleMania, Rhodes is fully expected to finish his story by challenging Reigns. Hours before SmackDown aired, there were also reports that   were backstage in Alabama. SmackDown also featured an appearance from Logan Paul, and women’s Royal Rumble winner Bayley declaring whom her WrestleMania 40 opponent will be and Last week’s broadcast of SmackDown garnered a viewership of 2.475 million. Logan Paul started off by saying they don’t want him here and he doesn’t want to be there either. Paul said Kevin Owens did more damage to Paul than Floyd Mayweather because Owens made him bleed. Getting the “what” treatment, Logan Paul mocked all the injured Superstars—CM Punk, Seth Rollins, etc.—while calling himself “unbreakable,” despite the fact that he did get  Logan Paul appeared on commentary, and Corey Graves seemed pretty awkward in the play-by-play role. Graves was hamstrung having to play the neutral party and not being able to cape for Logan Paul. He’s talented enough to eventually ease into this role, but it’s tough sledding early on. Austin Theory gets better every week. This week, Kevin Owens learned his lesson and used brass knuckles, but obscured them from the referee’s vision to ensure the victory. Prior to this Fatal 4-Way tag team match was a vignette showing Santos Escobar leading a toast to “eradicate” LWO. Joaquim Wilde asked the field “you wanna go viral?” before a handful of competitors launched him into the rest of the tag team. It was very impressive, but whether or not it will go viral remains to be seen. Wilde and Del Toro took everybody out, with help from Zelina Vega, who the turned her attention to Elektra Lopez with a Meteora. Pete Dunne and Tyler Bate won this match, meaning they advanced to the finals and will face the winners of the WWE Raw Fatal 4-Way tag team match. WWE rushed Bayley’s face-turn and feud with Iyo Sky as Damage CTRL were talking trash about Bayley backstage. Unfortunately for them, Bayley could overhear her. Wade Barrett lost a lot of credibility by saying he couldn’t wait to see whom Bayley was going to challenge, which came after Bayley overheard Iyo bashing Bayley backstage. Bayley began speaking Japanese to Damage CTRL, saying she could understand what they said behind her back. Bayley then challenged Iyo Sky in a great, if not rushed, moment. The Kabuki Warriors and Iyo then attacked Bayley as fans booed profusely. Bayley grabbed a pipe from under the ring and cleaned house. She then challenged Iyo Sky to a WrestleMania match as the crowd popped. Prior to this match was a brawl between Bobby Lashley and the Street Profits and the Final Testament. Team Lashley was saved by the returning B-Fab. This seems a way too early for Tiffany Stratton to compete on the main roster, but as a highly athletic gymnast, Stratton should eventually swim just fine after being thrown in the deep end. This was advertised as the SmackDown main event at 6:20, which means The Rock will probably cut his garden-variety half-hour promo. This wasn’t that bad of a debut for Stratton by any means. Roman Reigns eviscerated Seth Rollins. He started out by mentioning Rollins’ name, then saying “exactly, no pop!” He called Seth his “little brother.” He said Rollins can’t call himself the man running around in his wife’s clothes. He said Rollins broke his back three months into trying to carry WWE Raw. Then he began liming and asked Alabama if a workhorse “walks like this?” Reigns seemed legitimately annoyed by all the talk of him being a part-timer, saying he works 10-times less than Rollins but makes 10-times more money. This may have been the greatest promo of Reigns’ career. Crazy. Fans chanted “Cody!” as soon as Rhodes’ music cut off. Rhodes said he’s coming for Roman Reigns’ title, but not at WrestleMania. This prompted The Rock to return. The Rock faced off with Roman Reigns as SmackDown went off the air.

title: Can Sharapova Dominate In 'Exciting' Pickleball Debut?
content: Tennis legend Maria Sharapova poses for the media as she is unveiled as car manufacturer Porsche's  Tennis legend Maria Sharapova says that it doesn’t matter what sport she's playing. There is something about her that’s a constant: “Once a competitor, always a competitor.” The longtime world No. 1 and winner of all four singles Grand Slam events has taken up a new pastime, pickleball. Now that pickleball has captivated sports lovers all over the world, it has created interest not just in the growing Professional Pickleball Association (PPA) but has also drawn in many of the world's most beloved tennis stars. Sharapova is part of the highly-touted Pickleball Slam tournament, where she will join fellow tennis legends John McEnroe, Andre Agassi, and Steffi Graf this Sunday, Feb. 4, 2024, for the event called Pickleball Slam 2. Sharapova, who has thus far been waiting her turn to compete on the biggest of stages, hints that pickleball is not “just for fun” but brings out the top athlete in everyone, especially Hall of Fame-level tennis stars. “I think all the legends on the court come from very competitive backgrounds, and there will be no holding back, which will make it so much more exciting and fun,” Sharapova said during our interview Friday. “Every time I play, it's been really fun to see how much I giggle, but also how frustrated I can get during some of the games.” Sharapova adds that while playing and even practicing pickleball, her game will often“span a variety of emotions.” This weekend, tennis diehards will get to see the duo of Sharapova and McEnroe take on husband and wife team Agassi and Graf, who will compete for a $1 million purse. Pickleball Slam 2, created and produced by Horizon Sports & Experiences (HS&E) and InsideOut Sports & Entertainment (ISE), will be broadcast live during primetime on ESPN at 8:30 PM from Hard Rock Live at Seminole at the Hard Rock Hotel & Casino in Hollywood, Florida. During the inaugural Pickleball Slam event in April 2023, fans saw Agassi team up with Andy Roddick to beat McEnroe and Michael Chang and win the first $1 million purse, which was the largest tournament purse in pickleball history. Still, to Sharapova, who logged a 645–171 singles record over her 19-year career, playing pickleball is still relatively “new territory,” she said. “The main reason I wanted to participate in this event was to play against Steffi Graf, who I admired for so many years,” Sharapova explains. Graf, who retired from pro tennis in 1999, was the last tennis player to win the “Calendar Slam” in 1988 when she won the Australian Open, French Open, Wimbledon, and US Open within the same year. It wasn’t until 2004, the same year Graf was inducted into the International Tennis Hall of Fame, that Sharapova burst onto the scene at age 17 by winning Wimbledon, beating Serena Williams in two straight sets. “It’ll be great to compete against (Graf) and Andre with John—all of us playing this sport that’s having such a moment,” Sharapova said. “I’ve been practicing a bunch, so we’ll see. But I think John and I are going to be a formidable team.” Andre Agassi and Sharapova pose prior to a show match during the WTA Tennis tournament at the  David Levy, HS&E’s co-CEO/founder, said that he thinks this weekend’s Pickleball Slam 2 “is the ultimate showcase for the fastest-growing sport in the world.” “As we bring together four former world No. 1 tennis players to play for a $1M purse in primetime on ESPN, widespread fan interest in this year’s event is driving significant brand engagement.” Levy adds that big-time sponsors have been beating down the door, and in addition to Hard Rock, Slam 2’s host, State Farm, Brighthouse Financial, Franklin Sports, E*Trade, and AstraZeneca/Calquence have all jumped in to participate in sponsoring pickleball, one of the world’s fastest-growing sports. As an added authentic element this year, Levy said that “Florida residents can place bets on the Slam 2 via Hard Rock Bet.” But what about Sharapova’s legendary swing? I asked her whether her world-class tennis skills and big court movement work to her advantage in a small racket/paddle sport such as pickleball. “I was initially quite surprised by how different everything felt about pickleball. I thought there would be more similarities,” Sharapova said. “But I guess there's no such thing as ‘enough’ power.” Yet, along with her competitive mindset, Sharapova said that she thinks, come Sunday, she will “definitely use a lot of that strength that I had in my tennis career. But there’s a new skill set around hitting the short balls in the kitchen,”—or the non-volley zone, right in front of the net. “All these new terms that I'm becoming familiar with have been a very entertaining journey,” she added. “But overall, yeah, I think there are a few elements of tennis that you can bring in, but I'd say I was surprised at how different it felt.” Besides being a fresh new challenge for elite athletes and weekend warriors alike, Sharapova also thinks that pickleball has a bright future as a sport. “On the business side, it’s definitely growing, and how could it not? The engagement across the country is extremely high. You can see why people are really having fun with it.” Sharapova notes the growth of the game within tennis and recreation clubs all over America, “engaging with it and building pickle courts on their properties.” She admits that there are natural challenges to advancing any sport, but “by having more of it on TV and accessible to people,” she said, “it grows the game.” Of course, I had to ask the tennis phenom about her first love, tennis and the current crop of WTA stars making their mark. The two players that have stood out the most to Sharapova are world No. 3 Coco Gauff, who won last year’s US Open, and up-and-comer Mirra Andrea, the current WTA no. 35 player. “I've loved watching a new generation rise up to the occasion,” Sharapova. “I was so impressed with how Coco handled the victory in New York last year. Also, it’s great seeing the rise of new names and opportunities for athletes like Mirra Andreeva. Sharapova adds, “We’re seeing so much more consistency in the women's game and that has been really refreshing.” *****

title: Amazon Is Laying Off Hundreds Of Twitch, Prime Video And MGM Studios Employees
content: Amazon issued a memo to employees Wednesday morning announcing plans to cut “several hundred” workers in its Prime Video and MGM Studios, while its video game live streaming service Twitch is laying off around 500 people, marking the tech firm’s latest round of cuts after 2023 saw record-breaking layoffs for the company. Wednesday’s announcement follows a near record-breaking year for layoffs at Amazon Forbes obtained a copy of the internal memo from the departments’ Senior Vice President Mike Hopkins, which said they came to the decision following a review of “nearly every aspect of” the company’s business operations. Those impacted by the layoffs are expected to be told this week, with those in the Americas being notified by Wednesday afternoon and workers in other regions by the end of the week. Affected employees will be given “a separation payment, transitional benefits as applicable by country, and external job placement support,” according to the memo. Twitch is also   35% of its staff, or about 500 workers, due to unprofitability, CEO Dan Clancy announced Wednesday morning, after   reported Tuesday the company was preparing to announce the layoffs. “Throughout the past year, we’ve looked at nearly every aspect of our business with an eye towards improving our ability to deliver even more breakthrough movies, TV shows, and live sports in a personalized, easy to use entertainment experience for our global customers,” Hopkins said in the memo. “As a result, we’ve identified opportunities to reduce or discontinue investments in certain areas while increasing our investment and focus on content and product initiatives that deliver the most impact.” More than 27,000. That’s how many   Amazon   last year—a dramatic switch from the 2020   in hiring caused by pandemic-induced demand. Large U.S. companies across tech, healthcare, retail and beyond have increasingly cut costs over the past two years, resulting in a   in layoffs in 2023. Employers feared the economy could be thrown into a recession due to rising inflation and multiple rounds of interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. Dozens of the country’s biggest companies were not immune to such fears last year,   hundreds of thousands of jobs—with Amazon reducing its workforce by nearly 30,000. The retailer announced in late 2022 it would cut 18,000 employees, ultimately   another 9,000 in early 2023, with  throughout the year. The 18,000 workers the company cut last January was the largest set of layoffs in the company’s history, according to  . Amazon closed its   of MGM Studios in April 2022.  (Forbes)  (Forbes)  (Forbes)

title: Layoffs Hit 10-Month High As Financial And Tech Companies Slash 39,000 Jobs
content: January was one of the largest months for layoffs in almost 15 years, a new report by Challenger, Gray & Christmas said Thursday, as more than 82,000 people, largely in the technology and financial services sectors, were let go from their jobs. PayPal headquarters on Feb. 2, 2022 in San Jose, California.  A total of 82,307 people were laid off from U.S.-based employers last month, the report says, with companies citing restructuring, closing, market conditions and cost-cutting as the largest reasons for dramatic staffing changes. With the exception of January 2023, when 102,943 job cuts were announced, last month saw the highest number of layoffs since January 2009, when 241,749 people lost their jobs. Financial companies announced the most cuts in January (23,238), followed by the technology sector (15,806), food production industry (6,656) and retail sector (5,364). Hirings. U.S. employers announced plans to hire 5,376 workers in January, according to Challenger, Gray & Christmas, down significantly from January 2023, when companies had plans to hire 32,764 people. 224,000.
